title: Bexhill Walks

images.title: Boats in Egerton Park by Paul Gillett, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Boats in Egerton Park

images.title: Nigel Stickells / The Beach at Bexhill
images.caption: The Beach at Bexhill. Viewed adjacent to the promenade and nearby to the Clock Tower on Bexhill seafront. Eastbourne and Beachy Head are visible across the bay to the south-west.

images.title: Bill Johnson / Devonshire Square, Bexhill
images.caption: Devonshire Square, Bexhill. A view looking west towards Western Road, taken from the railway overbridge.

images.title: Nigel Stickells / The Colonnade Coffee House on Bexhill Seafront
images.caption: The Colonnade Coffee House on the Seafront. The east wing of the Colonnade is turned over to a Coffee House, deserted here on a sunny winter's morning. The inscription shown above the right-hand opening records that the Colonnade was designed by the Architect, J B Wall.

images.title: John Winfield / The Promenade, South Cliff, Cooden, Sussex
images.caption: The Promenade, South Cliff, Cooden, Sussex

images.title: Nigel Stickells / Folly in Egerton Park, Bexhill
images.caption: Folly in Egerton Park. This decorative folly is on an island in a pleasure lake that extends to the north side of Egerton Park.

images.title: Nigel Stickells / Bexhill Old Town - Looking Northwest
images.caption: Bexhill Old Town. A timbered framed historic building in the old section of the town.

description: Bexhill-on-Sea is a pleasant seaside town located in East Sussex. The town includes some fine Edwardian and Victorian architecture, while for walkers there are nice coastal trails along the promenade and a fine local park to explore. Bexhill is also notable as the Birthplace of British Motor Racing as it was the location for the first motor race in the United Kingdom, in May 1902. This walk from Bexhill visits the town's Egerton Park before heading west along the coast to Cooden Beach. The walk starts on the promenade in Bexhill and heads west to visit the lovely Egerton Park. Here there's a boating lake, waterways and a model yacht lake as well. After exploring the park you return to the sea front and head west along the shingle beach to Cooden Rocks. There's another shingle beach here which is popular with kite surfers and windsurfers. The walk can be extended by continuing west to visit Norman's Bay, the site where the Norman army landed in 1066 before the Battle of Hastings. Just beyond that is the historic Pevensey Castle where they army stayed before proceeding to the battle.
